chapter.title: Spring Cloud Stream Modules
chapter.simpara: This section goes into more detail about how you can work with Spring Cloud Stream Module as standalone applications or with Spring Cloud Data Flow.

section.title: File Source
section.simpara: This application polls a directory and sends new files or their contents to the output channel. The file source provides the contents of a File as a byte array by default. However, this can be customized using the --mode option:

listitem.simpara: ref Provides a java.io.File reference
lines Will split files line-by-line and emit a new message for each line
contents The default. Provides the contents of a file as a byte array

section.simpara: When using --mode=lines, you can also provide the additional option --withMarkers=true. If set to true, the underlying FileSplitter will emit additional start-of-file and end-of-file marker messages before and after the actual data. The payload of these 2 additional marker messages is of type FileSplitter.FileMarker. The option withMarkers defaults to false if not explicitly set.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The file source has the following options:

listitem.simpara: the absolute path to the directory to monitor for files (String, default: ``)
the fixed delay polling interval specified in seconds (int, default: 5)
an initial delay when using a fixed delay trigger, expressed in TimeUnits (seconds by default) (int, default: 0)
the maximum messages per poll; -1 for unlimited (long, default: -1)
specifies how the file is being read. By default the content of a file is provided as byte array (FileReadingMode, default: contents, possible values: ref,lines,contents)
a filter expression (Ant style) to accept only files that match the pattern (String, default: * )
whether to prevent the same file from being processed twice (boolean, default: true)
the time unit for the fixed and initial delays (String, default: SECONDS)
if true emits start of file/end of file marker messages before/after the data. Only valid with FileReadingMode 'lines' (Boolean, no default)

section.simpara: The ref option is useful in some cases in which the file contents are large and it would be more efficient to send the file path.

section.title: FTP Source
section.simpara: This source application supports transfer of files using the FTP protocol. Files are transferred from the remote directory to the local directory where the app is deployed. Messages emitted by the source are provided as a byte array by default. However, this can be customized using the --mode option:

listitem.simpara: ref Provides a java.io.File reference
lines Will split files line-by-line and emit a new message for each line
contents The default. Provides the contents of a file as a byte array

section.simpara: When using --mode=lines, you can also provide the additional option --withMarkers=true. If set to true, the underlying FileSplitter will emit additional start-of-file and end-of-file marker messages before and after the actual data. The payload of these 2 additional marker messages is of type FileSplitter.FileMarker. The option withMarkers defaults to false if not explicitly set.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The ftp source has the following options:

listitem.simpara: local directory must be auto created if it does not exist (boolean, default: true)
client mode to use : 2 for passive mode and 0 for active mode (int, default: 0)
delete remote files after transfer (boolean, default: false)
simple filename pattern to apply to the filter (String, default: *)
the rate at which to poll the remote directory (int, default: 1)
the host name for the FTP server (String, default: localhost)
an initial delay when using a fixed delay trigger, expressed in TimeUnits (seconds by default) (int, default: 0)
set the local directory the remote files are transferred to (String, default: ``)
the maximum messages per poll; -1 for unlimited (long, default: -1)
specifies how the file is being read. By default the content of a file is provided as byte array (FileReadingMode, default: contents, possible values: ref,lines,contents)
the password for the FTP connection (Password, no default)
the port for the FTP server (int, default: 21)
whether to preserve the timestamp of files retrieved (boolean, default: true)
the remote directory to transfer the files from (String, default: /)
file separator to use on the remote side (String, default: /)
the time unit for the fixed and initial delays (String, default: SECONDS)
extension to use when downloading files (String, default: .tmp)
the username for the FTP connection (String, no default)
if true emits start of file/end of file marker messages before/after the data. Only valid with FileReadingMode 'lines' (Boolean, no default)

section.title: Http Source
section.simpara: A source module that listens for HTTP requests and emits the body as a message payload. If the Content-Type matches text/* or application/json, the payload will be a String, otherwise the payload will be a byte array.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The http source supports the following configuration properties:

listitem.simpara: An Ant-Style pattern to determine which http requests will be captured (String, default: /)

section.title: JDBC Source
section.simpara: This source polls data from an RDBMS. This source is fully based on the DataSourceAutoConfiguration, so refer to the Spring Boot JDBC Support for more information.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The jdbc source has the following options:

listitem.simpara: the query to use to select data (String, no default, required)
an SQL update statement to execute for marking polled messages as 'seen' (String, no default)
whether to split the SQL result as individual messages (boolean, default: true)
max numbers of rows to process for each poll (int, default: 0)

section.simpara: Also see the Spring Boot Documentation for addition DataSource properties and TriggerProperties and MaxMessagesProperties for polling options.

section.title: JMS
section.simpara: The "jms" source enables receiving messages from JMS.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The jms source has the following options:

listitem.simpara: the session acknowledge mode (String, default: AUTO)
an identifier for the client, to be associated with a durable or shared topic subscription (String, no default)
the destination name from which messages will be received (String, no default)
a message selector to be applied to messages (String, no default)
when true, indicates the subscription to a topic is durable (boolean, default: false)
when true, indicates the subscription to a topic is shared (JMS 2.0) (boolean, default: false)
when true, indicates that the destination is a topic (boolean, default: false)
a name that will be assigned to the topic subscription (String, no default)
True to enable transactions and use a `DefaultMessageListenerContainer`, false to select a `SimpleMessageListenerContainer` (String, default: true)
The minimum number of consumer threads. *(Integer, default: 1)
The maximum number of consumer threads. Only supported when `sessionTransacted ` is true *(Integer, default: 1)

note.simpara: Spring boot broker configuration is used; refer to the Spring Boot Documentation for more information. The spring.jms.* properties above are also handled by the boot JMS support.

section.title: Load Generator (load-generator)
section.simpara: A source that sends generated data and dispatches it to the stream. This is to provide a method for users to identify the performance of Spring Cloud Data Flow in different environments and deployment types.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The load-generator source has the following options:

listitem.simpara: the number of messages to send (Integer, default: 100)
the size of message to send (Integer, 1000)
the number of producers (Integer, 1)
how this module should emit messages it produces (MimeType, default: no default)

section.title: RabbitMQ
section.simpara: The "rabbit" source enables receiving messages from RabbitMQ.
The queue(s) must exist before the stream is deployed; they are not created automatically. You can easily create a Queue using the RabbitMQ web UI.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The rabbit source has the following options:

listitem.simpara: enable retry; when retries are exhausted the message will be rejected; message disposition will depend on dead letter configuration (boolean, default: false)
initial interval between retries (int, default: 1000)
request message header names to be mapped from the incoming message (String, default: STANDARD_REQUEST_HEADERS)
maximum delivery attempts (int, default: 3)
the maximum number of consumers (int, default: 1)
maximum retry interval (int, default: 30000)
the queue(s) from which messages will be received (String, default: no default)
whether rejected messages will be requeued by default (boolean, default: true)
retry interval multiplier (double, default: 2.0)
true if the channel is to be transacted (boolean, default: false)

section.simpara: Also see the Spring Boot Documentation for addition properties for the broker connections and listener properties.

note.simpara: With the default ackMode (AUTO) and requeue (true) options, failed message deliveries will be retried indefinitely. Since there is not much processing in the rabbit source, the risk of failure in the source itself is small, unless the downstream Binder is not connected for some reason. Setting requeue to false will cause messages to be rejected on the first attempt (and possibly sent to a Dead Letter Exchange/Queue if the broker is so configured). The enableRetry option allows configuration of retry parameters such that a failed message delivery can be retried and eventually discarded (or dead-lettered) when retries are exhausted. The delivery thread is suspended during the retry interval(s). Retry options are enableRetry, maxAttempts, initialRetryInterval, retryMultiplier, and maxRetryInterval. Message deliveries failing with a MessageConversionException are never retried; the assumption being that if a message could not be converted on the first attempt, subsequent attempts will also fail. Such messages are discarded (or dead-lettered).

section.title: SFTP (sftp)
section.simpara: This source module supports transfer of files using the SFTP protocol. Files are transferred from the remote directory to the local directory where the module is deployed.
Messages emitted by the source are provided as a byte array by default. However, this can be customized using the --mode option:

listitem.simpara: ref Provides a java.io.File reference
lines Will split files line-by-line and emit a new message for each line
contents The default. Provides the contents of a file as a byte array

section.simpara: When using --mode=lines, you can also provide the additional option --withMarkers=true. If set to true, the underlying FileSplitter will emit additional start-of-file and end-of-file marker messages before and after the actual data. The payload of these 2 additional marker messages is of type FileSplitter.FileMarker. The option withMarkers defaults to false if not explicitly set.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The sftp source has the following options:

listitem.simpara: true to allow connecting to a host with an unknown or changed key (boolean, default: false)
if local directory must be auto created if it does not exist (boolean, default: true)
delete remote files after transfer (boolean, default: false)
fixed delay in SECONDS to poll the remote directory (int, default: 1)
the remote host to connect to (String, default: localhost)
an initial delay when using a fixed delay trigger, expressed in TimeUnits (seconds by default) (int, default: 0)
a SpEL expression location of known hosts file; required if 'allowUnknownKeys' is false; examples: systemProperties["user.home"]+"/.ssh/known_hosts", "/foo/bar/known_hosts" (String, no default)
set the local directory the remote files are transferred to (String, default: ``)
the maximum messages per poll; -1 for unlimited (long, default: -1)
specifies how the file is being read. By default the content of a file is provided as byte array (FileReadingMode, default: contents, possible values: ref,lines,contents)
the passphrase to use (String, default: ``)
the password for the provided user (String, default: ``)
simple filename pattern to apply to the filter (String, no default)
the remote port to connect to (int, default: 22)
the private key location (a valid Spring Resource URL) (String, default: ``)
filename regex pattern to apply to the filter (String, no default)
the remote directory to transfer the files from (String, no default)
the time unit for the fixed and initial delays (String, default: SECONDS)
extension to use when downloading files (String, default: .tmp)
the username to use (String, no default)
if true emits start of file/end of file marker messages before/after the data. Only valid with FileReadingMode 'lines' (Boolean, no default)

section.title: SYSLOG
section.simpara: The syslog source receives SYSLOG packets over UDP, TCP, or both. RFC3164 (BSD) and RFC5424 formats are supported.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The syslog source has the following options:

listitem.simpara: `udp`, `tcp`, or `both` (String, default tcp)
`3164` or `5424` (String, default 3164)
the port on which to listen (String, default 1514)
the maximum size allowed (TCP) (int, default 2048)
`true` to use NIO - only recommended when supporting many connections (Boolean, default false)
`true` to perform a reverse lookup on the remote IP address (Boolean, default false)
the socket timeout (long, default none)

section.title: TCP
section.simpara: The tcp source acts as a server and allows a remote party to connect to Spring Cloud Data Flow and submit data over a raw tcp socket.
TCP is a streaming protocol and some mechanism is needed to frame messages on the wire. A number of decoders are available, the default being 'CRLF' which is compatible with Telnet.
Messages produced by the TCP source module have a byte[] payload.

listitem.simpara: the size of the buffer (bytes) to use when decoding (int, default: 2048)
the decoder to use when receiving messages (Encoding, default: CRLF, possible values: CRLF,LF,NULL,STXETX,RAW,L1,L2,L4)
whether or not to use NIO (boolean, default: false)
the port on which to listen (int, default: 1234)
perform a reverse DNS lookup on the remote IP Address (boolean, default: false)
the timeout (ms) before closing the socket when no data is received (int, default: 120000)
whether or not to use direct buffers (boolean, default: false)
text terminated by carriage return (0x0d) followed by line feed (0x0a)
text terminated by line feed (0x0a)
text terminated by a null byte (0x00)
text preceded by an STX (0x02) and terminated by an ETX (0x03)
no structure - the client indicates a complete message by closing the socket
data preceded by a one byte (unsigned) length field (supports up to 255 bytes)
data preceded by a two byte (unsigned) length field (up to 216-1 bytes)
data preceded by a four byte (signed) length field (up to 231-1 bytes)

section.title: Time (time)
section.simpara: The time source will simply emit a String with the current time every so often.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The time source has the following options:

listitem.simpara: time delay between messages, expressed in TimeUnits (seconds by default) (int, default: 1)
how to render the current time, using SimpleDateFormat (String, default: yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss)
an initial delay when using a fixed delay trigger, expressed in TimeUnits (seconds by default) (int, default: 0)
the time unit for the fixed and initial delays (String, default: SECONDS)

section.title: Twitter Stream (twitterstream)
section.simpara: This source ingests data from Twitter’s streaming API v1.1. It uses the sample and filter stream endpoints rather than the full "firehose" which needs special access. The endpoint used will depend on the parameters you supply in the stream definition (some are specific to the filter endpoint).

You need to supply all keys and secrets (both consumer and accessToken) to authenticate for this source, so it is easiest if you just add these as the following environment variables: CONSUMER_KEY, CONSUMER_SECRET, ACCESS_TOKEN and ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET.
Stream creation is then straightforward:

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The twitterstream source has the following options:

listitem.simpara: a valid OAuth access token (String, no default)
an OAuth secret corresponding to the access token (String, no default)
a consumer key issued by twitter (String, no default)
consumer secret corresponding to the consumer key (String, no default)
language code e.g. 'en' (String, default: ``)

note.simpara: twitterstream emit JSON in the native Twitter format.

section.title: Filter (filter)
section.simpara: Use the filter module in a stream to determine whether a Message should be passed to the output channel.
The filter processor has the following options:

listitem.simpara: a SpEL expression used to transform messages (String, default: payload.toString())

section.title: Filter with SpEL expression
section.simpara: The simplest way to use the filter processor is to pass a SpEL expression when creating the stream. The expression should evaluate the message and return true or false. For example:
section.literallayout: dataflow:> stream create --name filtertest --definition "http --server.port=9000 | filter --expression=payload=='good' | log" --deploy
section.simpara: This filter will only pass Messages to the log sink if the payload is the word "good". Try sending "good" to the HTTP endpoint and you should see it in the Spring Cloud Data Flow logs:
Alternatively, if you send the word "bad" (or anything else), you shouldn’t see the log entry.

section.title: Groovy Filter (groovy-filter)
section.simpara: A Processor module that retains or discards messages according to a predicate, expressed as a Groovy script.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The groovy-filter processor has the following options:

listitem.simpara: The script resource location (String, default: ``)
Variable bindings as a comma delimited string of name-value pairs, e.g. 'foo=bar,baz=car' (String, default: ``)
The location of a properties file containing custom script variable bindings (String, default: ``)

section.title: Http Client (httpclient)
section.simpara: A processor module that makes requests to an HTTP resource and emits the response body as a message payload. This processor can be combined, e.g., with a time source module to periodically poll results from a HTTP resource.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The httpclient processor has the following options:

listitem.simpara: The URL to issue an http request to, as a static value.
A SpEL expression against incoming message to determine the URL to use.
The kind of http method to use.
The (static) body of the request to use.
A SpEL expression against incoming message to derive the request body to use.
A SpEL expression used to derive the http headers map to use.
The type used to interpret the response.
A SpEL expression used to compute the final result, applied against the whole http response.

section.title: Bridge (bridge)
section.simpara: A Processor module that returns messages that is passed by connecting just the input and output channels.

section.title: Groovy Transform (groovy-transform)
section.simpara: A Processor module that transforms messages using a Groovy script.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The groovy-transform processor has the following options:

listitem.simpara: The script resource location (String, default: ``)
Variable bindings as a comma delimited string of name-value pairs, e.g. 'foo=bar,baz=car' (String, default: ``)
The location of a properties file containing custom script variable bindings (String, default: ``)

section.title: Transform (transform)
section.simpara: Use the transform module in a stream to convert a Message’s content or structure.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The transform processor has the following options:

listitem.simpara: a SpEL expression used to transform messages (String, default: payload.toString())

section.title: Transform with SpEL expression
section.simpara: The simplest way to use the transform processor is to pass a SpEL expression when creating the stream. The expression should return the modified message or payload. For example:
section.literallayout: dataflow:> stream create --name transformtest --definition "http --server.port=9003 | transform --expression=payload.toUpperCase() | log" --deploy
section.simpara: This transform will convert all message payloads to upper case. If sending the word "foo" to the HTTP endpoint and you should see "FOO" in the Spring Cloud Data Flow logs:
As part of the SpEL expression you can make use of the pre-registered JSON Path function. The syntax is #jsonPath(payload,'<json path expression>')

section.title: Splitter
section.simpara: The splitter module builds upon the concept of the same name in Spring Integration and allows the splitting of a single message into several distinct messages.

listitem.simpara: a SpEL expression which would typically evaluate to an array or collection (String, default: null)
A list of delimiters to tokenize a String payload ('expression' must be null) (String, default: null)
Split File payloads, when true, START and END marker messages will be emitted, when false no markers are emitted (String, default: null)
Split File payloads using this charset to convert bytes to String (String, default: null)
Add correlation and sequence information to the message headers (String, default: true)

section.simpara: When no expression, fileMarkers, or charset is provided, a DefaultMessageSplitter is configured with (optional) delimiters. When fileMarkers or charset is provided, a FileSplitter is configured (you must provide either a fileMarkers or charset to split files, which must be text-based - they are split into lines). Otherwise, an ExpressionEvaluatingMessageSplitter is configured.
When splitting File payloads, the sequenceSize header is zero because the size cannot be determined at the beginning.

section.title: JSON Example
section.simpara: As part of the SpEL expression you can make use of the pre-registered JSON Path function. The syntax is #jsonPath(payload, '<json path expression>').
For example, consider the following JSON:
and an expression #jsonPath(payload, '$.store.book'); the result will be 4 messages, each with a Map payload containing the properties of a single book.

listitem.simpara: the compression to use for the transport (CompressionType, default: NONE, possible values: NONE,SNAPPY)
the consistencyLevel option of WriteOptions (ConsistencyLevel, no default, possible values: ANY,ONE,TWO,THREE,QUOROM,LOCAL_QUOROM,EACH_QUOROM,ALL,LOCAL_ONE,SERIAL,LOCAL_SERIAL)

section.title: Counter (counter)
section.simpara: A simple module that counts messages received, using Spring Boot metrics abstraction.

The name of a store used to store the counter. (String, default: memory, possible values: memory, redis)

section.title: File (file)
section.simpara: This module writes each message it receives to a file.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The file sink has the following options:

listitem.simpara: if false, will append a newline character at the end of each line (boolean, default: false)
the charset to use when writing a String payload (String, default: UTF-8)
the directory in which files will be created (String, default: ``)

section.title: FTP Sink (ftp)
section.simpara: FTP sink is a simple option to push files to an FTP server from incoming messages.
It uses an ftp-outbound-adapter, therefore incoming messages could be either a java.io.File object, a String (content of the file) or an array of bytes (file content as well).
To use this sink, you need a username and a password to login.

note.simpara: By default Spring Integration will use o.s.i.file.DefaultFileNameGenerator if none is specified. DefaultFileNameGenerator will determine the file name based on the value of the file_name header (if it exists) in the MessageHeaders, or if the payload of the Message is already a java.io.File, then it will use the original name of that file.

section.title: Gemfire (gemfire)
section.simpara: A sink module that allows one to write message payloads to a Gemfire server.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The gemfire sink has the following options:

listitem.simpara: a comma separated list of [host]:[port] specifying either locator or server addresses for the client connection pool (String, localhost:10334)
a SpEL expression which is evaluated to create a cache key (String, default: the value is currently the message payload')
port of the cache server or locator (if useLocator=true). May be a comma delimited list (String, no default)
name of the region to use when storing data (String, default: ${spring.application.name})
'server' or 'locator' (String, default: locator)

section.title: Hadoop (HDFS) (hdfs)
section.simpara: If you do not have Hadoop installed, you can install Hadoop as described in our separate guide.
Once Hadoop is up and running, you can then use the hdfs sink when creating a stream

In the above example, we’ve scheduled time source to automatically send ticks to hdfs once in every second. If you wait a little while for data to accumuluate you can then list can then list the files in the hadoop filesystem using the shell’s built in hadoop fs commands. Before making any access to HDFS in the shell you first need to configure the shell to point to your name node. This is done using the hadoop config command.

In this example the hdfs protocol is used but you may also use the webhdfs protocol. Listing the contents in the output directory (named by default after the stream name) is done by issuing the following command.
section.literallayout: dataflow:>hadoop fs ls /xd/myhdfsstream1 Found 1 items -rw-r--r-- 3 jvalkealahti supergroup 0 2013-12-18 18:10 /xd/myhdfsstream1/myhdfsstream1-0.txt.tmp
section.simpara: While the file is being written to it will have the tmp suffix. When the data written exceeds the rollover size (default 1GB) it will be renamed to remove the tmp suffix. There are several options to control the in use file file naming options. These are --inUsePrefix and --inUseSuffix set the file name prefix and suffix respectfully.
When you destroy a stream
and list the stream directory again, in use file suffix doesn’t exist anymore.
section.literallayout: dataflow:>hadoop fs ls /xd/myhdfsstream1 Found 1 items -rw-r--r-- 3 jvalkealahti supergroup 380 2013-12-18 18:10 /xd/myhdfsstream1/myhdfsstream1-0.txt
section.simpara: To list the list the contents of a file directly from a shell execute the hadoop cat command.

In the above examples we didn’t yet go through why the file was written in a specific directory and why it was named in this specific way. Default location of a file is defined as /xd/<stream name>/<stream name>-<rolling part>.txt. These can be changed using options --directory and --fileName respectively. Example is shown below.
section.literallayout: dataflow:>stream create --name myhdfsstream2 --definition "time | hdfs --directory=/xd/tmp --fileName=data" --deploy dataflow:>stream destroy --name myhdfsstream2 dataflow:>hadoop fs ls /xd/tmp Found 1 items -rw-r--r-- 3 jvalkealahti supergroup 120 2013-12-18 18:31 /xd/tmp/data-0.txt
section.simpara: It is also possible to control the size of a files written into HDFS. The --rollover option can be used to control when file currently being written is rolled over and a new file opened by providing the rollover size in bytes, kilobytes, megatypes, gigabytes, and terabytes.
section.literallayout: dataflow:>stream create --name myhdfsstream3 --definition "time | hdfs --rollover=100" --deploy dataflow:>stream destroy --name myhdfsstream3 dataflow:>hadoop fs ls /xd/myhdfsstream3 Found 3 items -rw-r--r-- 3 jvalkealahti supergroup 100 2013-12-18 18:41 /xd/myhdfsstream3/myhdfsstream3-0.txt -rw-r--r-- 3 jvalkealahti supergroup 100 2013-12-18 18:41 /xd/myhdfsstream3/myhdfsstream3-1.txt -rw-r--r-- 3 jvalkealahti supergroup 100 2013-12-18 18:41 /xd/myhdfsstream3/myhdfsstream3-2.txt
section.simpara: Shortcuts to specify sizes other than bytes are written as --rollover=64M, --rollover=512G or --rollover=1T.
The stream can also be compressed during the write operation. Example of this is shown below.
section.literallayout: dataflow:>stream create --name myhdfsstream4 --definition "time | hdfs --codec=gzip" --deploy dataflow:>stream destroy --name myhdfsstream4 dataflow:>hadoop fs ls /xd/myhdfsstream4 Found 1 items -rw-r--r-- 3 jvalkealahti supergroup 80 2013-12-18 18:48 /xd/myhdfsstream4/myhdfsstream4-0.txt.gzip
section.simpara: From a native os shell we can use hadoop’s fs commands and pipe data into gunzip.

Often a stream of data may not have a high enough rate to roll over files frequently, leaving the file in an opened state. This prevents users from reading a consistent set of data when running mapreduce jobs. While one can alleviate this problem by using a small rollover value, a better way is to use the idleTimeout option that will automatically close the file if there was no writes during the specified period of time. This feature is also useful in cases where burst of data is written into a stream and you’d like that data to become visible in HDFS.

note.simpara: The idleTimeout value should not exceed the timeout values set on the Hadoop cluster. These are typically configured using the dfs.socket.timeout and/or dfs.datanode.socket.write.timeout properties in the hdfs-site.xml configuration file.

section.simpara: In the above example we changed a source to http order to control what we write into a hdfs sink. We defined a small rollover size and a timeout of 10 seconds. Now we can simply post data into this stream via source end point using a below command.

If we repeat the command very quickly and then wait for the timeout we should be able to see that some files are closed before rollover size was met and some were simply rolled because of a rollover size.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The hdfs sink has the following options:

listitem.simpara: timeout in ms, regardless of activity, after which file will be automatically closed (long, default: 0)
compression codec alias name (gzip, snappy, bzip2, lzo, or slzo) (String, default: ``)
where to output the files in the Hadoop FileSystem (String, default: /tmp/hdfs-sink)
the base filename extension to use for the created files (String, default: txt)
the base filename to use for the created files (String, default: <stream name>)
maximum number of file open attempts to find a path (int, default: 10)
whether file name should contain uuid (boolean, default: false)
the URI to use to access the Hadoop FileSystem (String, default: ${spring.hadoop.fsUri})
inactivity timeout in ms after which file will be automatically closed (long, default: 0)
prefix for files currently being written (String, default: ``)
suffix for files currently being written (String, default: .tmp)
whether writer is allowed to overwrite files in Hadoop FileSystem (boolean, default: false)
a SpEL expression defining the partition path (String, default: ``)
threshold in bytes when file will be automatically rolled over (String, default: 1G)

note.simpara: In the context of the fileOpenAttempts option, attempt is either one rollover request or failed stream open request for a path (if another writer came up with a same path and already opened it).

section.title: Partition Path Expression
section.simpara: SpEL expression is evaluated against a Spring Messaging Message passed internally into a HDFS writer. This allows expression to use headers and payload from that message. While you could do a custom processing within a stream and add custom headers, timestamp is always going to be there. Data to be written is then available in a payload.

section.title: Accessing Properties
section.simpara: Using a payload simply returns whatever is currently being written. Access to headers is via headers property. Any other property is automatically resolved from headers if found. For example headers.timestamp is equivalent to timestamp.

section.title: Custom Methods
section.simpara: Addition to a normal SpEL functionality, few custom methods has been added to make it easier to build partition paths. These custom methods can be used to work with a normal partition concepts like date formatting, lists, ranges and hashes.

section.title: path
section.simpara: Concatenates paths together with a delimiter /. This method can be used to make the expression less verbose than using a native SpEL functionality to combine path parts together. To create a path part1/part2, expression 'part1' + '/' + 'part2' is equivalent to path('part1','part2').

listitem.simpara: Any number of path parts

formalpara.title: Return Value
formalpara.para: Concatenated value of paths delimited with /.

section.title: dateFormat
section.programlisting: dateFormat(String pattern) dateFormat(String pattern, Long epoch) dateFormat(String pattern, Date date) dateFormat(String pattern, String datestring) dateFormat(String pattern, String datestring, String dateformat)
section.simpara: Creates a path using date formatting. Internally this method delegates into SimpleDateFormat and needs a Date and a pattern. On default if no parameter used for conversion is given, timestamp is expected. Effectively dateFormat('yyyy') equals to dateFormat('yyyy', timestamp) or dateFormat('yyyy', headers.timestamp).

Method signature with three parameters can be used to create a custom Date object which is then passed to SimpleDateFormat conversion using a dateformat pattern. This is useful in use cases where partition should be based on a date or time string found from a payload content itself. Default dateformat pattern if omitted is yyyy-MM-dd.

listitem.simpara: Pattern compatible with SimpleDateFormat to produce a final output.
Timestamp as Long which is converted into a Date.
A Date to be formatted.
Secondary pattern to convert datestring into a Date.
Date as a String

formalpara.title: Return Value
formalpara.para: A path part representation which can be a simple file or directory name or a directory structure.

section.title: list
section.simpara: Creates a partition path part by matching a source against a lists denoted by lists.

Lets assume that data is being written and it’s possible to extrace an appid either from headers or payload. We can automatically do a list based partition by using a partition method list(headers.appid,{{'1TO3','APP1','APP2','APP3'},{'4TO6','APP4','APP5','APP6'}}). This method would create three partitions, 1TO3_list, 4TO6_list and list. Latter is used if no match is found from partition lists passed to lists.

listitem.simpara: An Object to be matched against lists.
A definition of list of lists.

formalpara.title: Return Value
formalpara.para: A path part prefixed with a matched key i.e. XXX_list or list if no match.

section.title: range
section.simpara: Creates a partition path part by matching a source against a list denoted by list using a simple binary search.

The partition method takes a source as first argument and list as a second argument. Behind the scenes this is using jvms binarySearch which works on an Object level so we can pass in anything. Remember that meaningful range match only works if passed in Object and types in list are of same type like Integer. Range is defined by a binarySearch itself so mostly it is to match against an upper bound except the last range in a list. Having a list of {1000,3000,5000} means that everything above 3000 will be matched with 5000. If that is an issue then simply adding Integer.MAX_VALUE as last range would overflow everything above 5000 into a new partition. Created partitions would then be 1000_range, 3000_range and 5000_range.

listitem.simpara: An Object to be matched against list.
A definition of list.

formalpara.title: Return Value
formalpara.para: A path part prefixed with a matched key i.e. XXX_range.

section.title: hash
section.simpara: Creates a partition path part by calculating hashkey using source`s hashCode and bucketcount. Using a partition method hash(timestamp,2) would then create partitions named 0_hash, 1_hash and 2_hash. Number suffixed with _hash is simply calculated using Object.hashCode() % bucketcount.

listitem.simpara: An Object which hashCode will be used.
A number of buckets

formalpara.title: Return Value
formalpara.para: A path part prefixed with a hash key i.e. XXX_hash.

section.title: RabbitMQ
section.simpara: The "rabbit" sink enables outbound messaging over RabbitMQ.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The rabbit sink has the following options:
(See the Spring Boot documentation for RabbitMQ connection properties)

listitem.simpara: the bean name of the message converter (String, default: none)
the default delivery mode, true for persistent (boolean, default: false)

note.simpara: By default, the message converter is a SimpleMessageConverter which handles byte[], String and java.io.Serializable. section.title: Dynamic Router (router)
section.simpara: The Dynamic Router support allows for routing messages to named destinations based on the evaluation of a SpEL expression or Groovy Script.

section.title: SpEL-based Routing
section.simpara: The expression evaluates against the message and returns either a channel name, or the key to a map of channel names.
For more information, please see the "Routers and the Spring Expression Language (SpEL)" subsection in the Spring Integration Reference manual Configuring (Generic) Router section.

section.title: Groovy-based Routing
section.simpara: Instead of SpEL expressions, Groovy scripts can also be used. Let’s create a Groovy script in the file system at "file:/my/path/router.groovy", or "classpath:/my/path/router.groovy" :

If you want to pass variable values to your script, you can statically bind values using the variables option or optionally pass the path to a properties file containing the bindings using the propertiesLocation option. All properties in the file will be made available to the script as variables. You may specify both variables and propertiesLocation, in which case any duplicate values provided as variables override values provided in propertiesLocation. Note that payload and headers are implicitly bound to give you access to the data contained in a message.
For more information, see the Spring Integration Reference manual Groovy Support.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The router sink has the following options:

listitem.simpara: comma-delimited destinations mapped from evaluation results (String, no default)
Where to route messages where the channel cannot be resolved (String, default: nullChannel)
a SpEL expression used to determine the destination (String, default: headers['routeTo'])
the path of a properties file containing custom script variable bindings (String, no default)
how often to check (in milliseconds) whether the script (if present) has changed; -1 for never (long, default: 60000)
reference to a script used to process messages (String, no default)
Destination mappings as a new line delimited string of name-value pairs, e.g. 'foo=bar\n baz=car'. (String, no default)

note.simpara: Since this is a dynamic router, destinations are created as needed; therefore, by default the defaultOutputChannel and resolutionRequired will only be used if the Binder has some problem binding to the destination.

section.simpara: You can restrict the creation of dynamic bindings using the spring.cloud.stream.dynamicDestinations property. By default, all resolved destinations will be bound dynamically; if this property has a comma-delimited list of destination names, only those will be bound. Messages that resolve to a destination that is not in this list will be routed to the defaultOutputChannel, which must also appear in the list.
destinationMappings are used to map the evaluation results to an actual destination name.

section.title: TCP Sink
section.simpara: The TCP Sink provides for outbound messaging over TCP; messages sent to the sink can have String or byte[] payloads.
TCP is a streaming protocol and some mechanism is needed to frame messages on the wire. A number of encoders are available, the default being 'CRLF'.

section.title: Options
section.simpara: The tcp sink has the following options:

listitem.simpara: the charset used when converting from String to bytes (String, default: UTF-8)
whether to close the socket after each message (boolean, default: false)
the encoder to use when sending messages (Encoding, default: CRLF, possible values: CRLF,LF,NULL,STXETX,RAW,L1,L2,L4)
the remote host to connect to (String, default: localhost)
whether or not to use NIO (boolean, default: false)
the port on the remote host to connect to (int, default: 1234)
perform a reverse DNS lookup on the remote IP Address (boolean, default: false)
the timeout (ms) before closing the socket when no data is received (int, default: 120000)
whether or not to use direct buffers (boolean, default: false)
text terminated by carriage return (0x0d) followed by line feed (0x0a)
text terminated by line feed (0x0a)
text terminated by a null byte (0x00)
text preceded by an STX (0x02) and terminated by an ETX (0x03)
no structure - the client indicates a complete message by closing the socket
data preceded by a one byte (unsigned) length field (supports up to 255 bytes)
data preceded by a two byte (unsigned) length field (up to 216-1 bytes)
data preceded by a four byte (signed) length field (up to 231-1 bytes)

section.simpara: To build the source you will need to install JDK 1.7.

The build uses the Maven wrapper so you don’t have to install a specific version of Maven. To enable the tests for Redis you should run the server before bulding. See below for more information on how run Redis.
The main build command is
You can also add '-DskipTests' if you like, to avoid running the tests.

note.simpara: You can also install Maven (>=3.3.3) yourself and run the mvn command in place of ./mvnw in the examples below. If you do that you also might need to add -P spring if your local Maven settings do not contain repository declarations for spring pre-release artifacts.

Be aware that you might need to increase the amount of memory available to Maven by setting a MAVEN_OPTS environment variable with a value like -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=128m. We try to cover this in the .mvn configuration, so if you find you have to do it to make a build succeed, please raise a ticket to get the settings added to source control.

section.simpara: The projects that require middleware generally include a docker-compose.yml, so consider using Docker Compose to run the middeware servers in Docker containers. See the README in the scripts demo repository for specific instructions about the common cases of mongo, rabbit and redis.

section.title: Working with the code
section.simpara: If you don’t have an IDE preference we would recommend that you use Spring Tools Suite or Eclipse when working with the code. We use the m2eclipe eclipse plugin for maven support. Other IDEs and tools should also work without issue.

section.title: Importing into eclipse with m2eclipse
section.simpara: We recommend the m2eclipe eclipse plugin when working with eclipse. If you don’t already have m2eclipse installed it is available from the "eclipse marketplace".

Unfortunately m2e does not yet support Maven 3.3, so once the projects are imported into Eclipse you will also need to tell m2eclipse to use the .settings.xml file for the projects. If you do not do this you may see many different errors related to the POMs in the projects. Open your Eclipse preferences, expand the Maven preferences, and select User Settings. In the User Settings field click Browse and navigate to the Spring Cloud project you imported selecting the .settings.xml file in that project. Click Apply and then OK to save the preference changes.

note.simpara: Alternatively you can copy the repository settings from .settings.xml into your own ~/.m2/settings.xml.

chapter.title: Contributing
chapter.simpara: Spring Cloud is released under the non-restrictive Apache 2.0 license, and follows a very standard Github development process, using Github tracker for issues and merging pull requests into master. If you want to contribute even something trivial please do not hesitate, but follow the guidelines below.

section.title: Sign the Contributor License Agreement
section.simpara: Before we accept a non-trivial patch or pull request we will need you to sign the contributor’s agreement. Signing the contributor’s agreement does not grant anyone commit rights to the main repository, but it does mean that we can accept your contributions, and you will get an author credit if we do. Active contributors might be asked to join the core team, and given the ability to merge pull requests.

section.title: Code Conventions and Housekeeping
section.simpara: None of these is essential for a pull request, but they will all help. They can also be added after the original pull request but before a merge.

listitem.simpara: Use the Spring Framework code format conventions. If you use Eclipse you can import formatter settings using the eclipse-code-formatter.xml file from the Spring Cloud Build project. If using IntelliJ, you can use the Eclipse Code Formatter Plugin to import the same file.
Add the ASF license header comment to all new .java files (copy from existing files in the project)
Add yourself as an @author to the .java files that you modify substantially (more than cosmetic changes).
Add some Javadocs and, if you change the namespace, some XSD doc elements.
A few unit tests would help a lot as well — someone has to do it.
If no-one else is using your branch, please rebase it against the current master (or other target branch in the main project).
When writing a commit message please follow these conventions, if you are fixing an existing issue please add Fixes gh-XXXX at the end of the commit message (where XXXX is the issue number).
